personalized_feedback:
Om — I’ve really enjoyed watching your shift from ad-hoc intuition to the DRIVER way of thinking. In your recent assignments you consistently broke complex problems into clear drivers (revenue per user, churn, CAC), tied each driver to a measurable assumption, and showed the causal chain from assumptions to value — exactly the systematic discipline we aim for. Your explanations of why particular drivers matter for unit economics showed real financial intuition, and your stepwise reasoning made it easy to follow how changes propagate through the model.

For next steps, focus on two practical areas that will bring your models closer to real business decision-making. First, tighten the technical implementation: before drawing conclusions, build quick checks for edge cases and inconsistent inputs (for example, negative churn or impossible conversion rates). Practically, add simple validation rules and a “sanity check” section that flags suspect assumptions. Second, strengthen the finance–technology integration: connect your driver-level outputs to business KPIs and decision triggers. For instance, translate scenario outputs into actionable recommendations (hire, marketing spend increase, pricing change) and sketch how a data feed or dashboard would update those drivers in production. Useful exercises: run sensitivity analyses on top 3 drivers, produce a one-page executive brief that links model outcomes to next-quarter actions, and prototype a mock data refresh workflow.

Keep treating DRIVER as a muscle, not a checklist. The habit of decomposing problems into drivers, testing assumptions, and mapping outcomes to business actions will set you apart in product finance, strategy, or corporate development roles. I’m excited to see how you apply these next steps in your next submission — you’re on a real trajectory.
